metadata.title: Inactivation of porcine epidemic diarrhea virus using heated water

abstract.original_text: A B S T R A C T Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PEDV) is a very contagious swine pathogen that spreads easily via the fecaloral route, notably from contaminated fomites. The present study investigated heated water as a method for rapid thermal inactivation of PEDV. Cell-culture adapted PEDV was treated with water at varying temperatures and viral titers were measured at multiple time points post-treatment. Viable PEDV was not recovered after a ten second or longer treatment with water heated to ≥76°C; however, PEDV nucleic acid was detected in all samples regardless of treatment. Hot water decontamination could be considered in settings where chemical disinfection is impractical.
